title.value: FusionRetro: Molecule Representation Fusion via In-Context Learning for Retrosynthetic Planning
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: FusionRetro: Molecule Representation Fusion via In-Context Learning for Retrosynthetic Planning

extractions.description: The paper proposes FusionRetro, a novel framework that utilizes context information for retrosynthetic planning. The approach incorporates context through three steps: encoding molecules into embeddings, aggregating information over routes, and readout to predict reactants. FusionRetro is the first to use in-context learning for retrosynthesis prediction and demonstrates improved performance over baseline methods.

type.justification: The paper presents a novel model, conducts experiments, and provides empirical results to demonstrate improved performance, which is characteristic of empirical studies.
type.quote: Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that by fusing in the context information over routes, our model significantly improves the performance of retrosynthetic planning over baselines that are not context-aware, especially for long synthetic routes.

name.justification: The paper focuses on retrosynthetic planning, which is a task within computational chemistry aimed at predicting chemical reactions for molecule synthesis.
name.quote: Retrosynthetic planning aims to devise a complete multi-step synthetic route from starting materials to a target molecule.

name.justification: The paper discusses the application of machine learning techniques specifically in the context of computational chemistry for retrosynthetic planning.
name.quote: In the past few years, with the advancement in deep learning, there has been increasing interest in applying machine learning to retrosynthetic planning, a sub-topic of Computer-Aided Synthesis Planning (CASP).

name.justification: The paper utilizes graph-based models and message passing, which are central concepts in graph neural networks.
name.quote: Our framework, focusing on retrosynthesis prediction, is a modular framework comprising encoding, fusion, and readout components. Our fusion leverages in-context learning to maximize the use of in-context reactions. Importantly, it is not limited to GNNs alone and can incorporate various aggregation methodologies, such as Transformer (Vaswani et al., 2017) and Graph Transformer (Ying et al., 2021).

name.justification: FusionRetro is presented as the primary model introduced in the paper.
name.quote: In this work, we propose a novel framework that utilizes context information for improved retrosynthetic planning. We propose a novel and principled context-aware model by fusing in the context embeddings, named FusionRetro.

is_contributed.justification: FusionRetro is the primary contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce a novel and principled context-aware model by fusing in the context embeddings, named FusionRetro.

is_executed.justification: The paper includes practical experimentation, implying model execution.
is_executed.quote: Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that by fusing in the context information over routes, our model significantly improves the performance of retrosynthetic planning over baselines that are not context-aware, especially for long synthetic routes.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares FusionRetro against existing baseline methods, showing its improved performance.
is_compared.quote: Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that by fusing in the context information over routes, our model significantly improves the performance of retrosynthetic planning over baselines that are not context-aware, especially for long synthetic routes.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper title provided for FusionRetro since it is introduced in the current paper.

name.justification: Retro* is used as a baseline model for evaluating the performance of FusionRetro.
name.quote: As a quantitative illustration in Figure 1, when we combine existing one-step models with top-5 accuracies between 60 and 80 percents with Retro* (Chen et al., 2020), an established search algorithm, the search success rates easily reach over 85 and 94 percents respectively.

is_contributed.justification: Retro* is used for comparison and is not contributed by the authors of the current paper.
is_contributed.quote: when we combine existing one-step models with top-5 accuracies between 60 and 80 percents with Retro* (Chen et al., 2020).

is_executed.justification: Retro* is used in experimental evaluations, indicating it was executed.
is_executed.quote: when we combine existing one-step models with top-5 accuracies between 60 and 80 percents with Retro*

is_compared.justification: Retro* is compared against FusionRetro in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: As a quantitative illustration in Figure 1, when we combine existing one-step models with top-5 accuracies between 60 and 80 percents with Retro*

referenced_paper_title.value: Retro*: learning retrosynthetic planning with neural guided a* search
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for Retro* is provided in the text.

name.justification: Neuralsym is one of the baseline models used for comparison in the experiments.

is_contributed.justification: Neuralsym is not introduced by the authors of the current paper but is used for comparison.

is_executed.justification: Neuralsym is used in the experimental evaluation, implying execution.

is_compared.justification: Neuralsym is compared against FusionRetro in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: Retrosim (Coley et al., 2017), Neuralsym (Segler & Waller, 2017), and GLN (Dai et al., 2019).

referenced_paper_title.value: Neural-Symbolic Machine Learning for Retrosynthesis and Reaction Prediction
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for Neuralsym is provided in the text.

name.justification: Transformer is used as one of the baseline models for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: The template-free baseline approaches we consider include...Transformer (Karpov et al., 2019).

is_contributed.justification: Transformer is a well-known architecture used as a baseline and not introduced in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: The template-free baseline approaches we consider include...Transformer (Karpov et al., 2019).

is_executed.justification: Transformer is used in the experimental evaluation, implying execution.
is_executed.quote: Transformer is implemented using Pytorch (Paszke et al., 2019)

is_compared.justification: Transformer is compared against FusionRetro in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: We also evaluate end-to-end template-free approaches such as Transformer (Karpov et al., 2019).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for Transformer is provided in the text.

name.justification: USPTO-full is utilized to construct the benchmark for evaluating single-step retrosynthesis models.
name.quote: We construct a benchmark for retrosynthetic planning using the public USPTO-full dataset, which consists of 906,164 valid reactions from the original 1,808,937, after removing invalid and duplicate ones.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific reference provided for USPTO-full in the text.

name.justification: USPTO-50K is used in comparative single-step retrosynthesis prediction analysis.
name.quote: Approximately 95% of reactions in the USPTO-50K dataset have only one reaction center due to heavy filtering.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific reference provided for USPTO-50K in the text.

name.justification: Pytorch is explicitly mentioned as the framework used for implementing the Transformer baseline model.
name.quote: Transformer is implemented using Pytorch (Paszke et al., 2019)

referenced_paper_title.value: Pytorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for Pytorch is provided in the text.
